Award.AwardTitle: Investigations of Binary Star Properties and Evolutionary Processes with the CHARA Array Interferometer
Award.AbstractNarration:
Long baseline optical interferometry allows measurement (and even imaging) of structure on smaller scales than can be obtained even with the largest ground-based telescopes. The investigators will continue to make excellent use of Georgia State's Center for High Angular Resolution Astronomy (CHARA) interferometer array on Mt. Wilson in California. This is the only long-baseline optical interferometer run by a university, so it provides a unique opportunity for student training in this state-of-the art technology. Results from this program will be featured in undergraduate classes at Georgia State and in the southern California public outreach efforts of the Mt. Wilson Institute.

The proposal presents a three-part investigation that will use the CHARA optical long-baseline interferometer array to determine fundamental stellar and circumstellar properties of stars in close binary systems before, during, and after they interact and exchange mass. The high angular resolution provided by interferometry will permit them to measure the orbits of over 200 non-interacting spectroscopic binaries, which will allow direct determination of component masses and indirect determination of other physical parameters. They will also be able to image circumstellar material in binary stars that are currently exchanging material. Finally, they will search for the poorly-stuied donor stars in a carefully-selected sample of systems that have already undergone mass transfer.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The stars are distant Suns that are so far away that scientists need special tools
to examine them in any detail.  The ability to see small details (high angular
resolution) depends on the diameter of the telescope lens or mirror, but to build
a single telescope large enough to see even the largest stars is prohibitively
expensive.  The solution is to build a network of distributed telescopes, known
as an optical interferometer.  The nation's leading optical long baseline
interferometer is the Georgia State University Center for High Angular Resolution
Astronomy (CHARA) Array, a system of six telescopes at the Mount Wilson Observatory
in southern California.  These telescopes have separations (baselines) ranging from
34 to 331 meters (see Fig. 1 for the arrangement), effectively making a telescope
as large as three football fields placed end-to-end.   The light is combined from
each telescope (each with a 1 meter primary mirror; Fig. 2) by sending the beams
along light pipes into a central optics laboratory (Fig. 3).  There the beams
come together to study the details of the visual and near infrared light of the stars.

The CHARA Array provided the means to make several in depth studies of very distant
stars with masses greater than that of the Sun.  Measurements were made of the
hot and massive O- and B-type stars, objects that burn quickly through their
nuclear fuel to explode as supernovae and create neutron stars and black hole
remnants.  By combining the angular size with distant estimates from the European
Space Agency's Gaia Mission, the physical radii of these stars are determined
and compared to computer models of their interior structure and radiative flux
output.  The other key measure of a star is its mass, and masses can be found by
tracking the orbital motion of pairs of stars forming a binary system.  The CHARA
Array is ideal for mapping out the angular orbits of close pairs discovered by
the time variable Doppler shifts of their spectra.  For example, observations
from the Array provided the first three-dimensional orbital map of the binary
star system sigma Orionis, leading to mass estimates with 1% accuracy and a
distance set with an accuracy of 0.3%.

The other method to find orbital orientations and masses of stellar pairs is
to study the variable light output of eclipsing binary stars in which the flux
changes as each component mutually transits in front of the other star.  The NASA
Kepler mission to find planets around other stars through similar planetary transits
created the most accurate eclipsing binary light curves ever made, and a second part
of this NSF-sponsored program was a spectroscopic follow up campaign to obtain
Doppler shift (or radial velocity) curves of the projected motions of 41 eclipsing
binaries in the Kepler field of view.  This analysis led to accurate measurements of
stellar masses, radii, temperatures, and spin rates, so that the physical and
pulsational properties of these stars could be critically compared to computer
models that track the changes in stellar parameters as stars age.

Pairs of massive stars in close orbits are destined to interact over time in ways
that dramatically transform both components.  As the initially more massive star
grows in size, its outer gas layers will be pulled by the gravity of the companion
star until it is stripped down to its nuclear-burning core.  The result is then
a pair composed of a small but very hot, mass donor star in orbit around an
enlarged and rapidly rotating, mass gainer star.  Detecting such systems is
very difficult because the stripped-down star is lost in the glare of the much
brighter mass gainer.  However, the search is more favorable in the ultraviolet
part of the spectrum where the hot core contributes relatively more of the starlight.
A systematic and large scale search for such transformed pairs was made using data
from the archive of the NASA International Ultraviolet Explorer satellite, and this
effort increased the number of known pairs from three to sixteen.  One such system,
phi Persei, was detected and its orbit mapped using the CHARA Array.  This work
provides us with a first glimpse of the kinds of binary star systems that will
eventually become pairs of orbiting neutron stars, such as the pair that spiraled
together and merged in an explosion and burst of gravitational waves that was
observed in 2017 by the Laser Interferometer Gravitational-Wave Observatory.
